Blew or Violet when viewed very obliquely hath been cha[nged?]
to a deep red. But the changes of these colours are not so 
Sensible as of those made by water. For the Scoria or 
vitrified part of the Mettall, wch most Mettalls when heat[ed]
or Melted continually protrude to their surface, where by 
covering them in forme of a thin glassy skin it causes then 
colours, is much denser then water; And I finde, that the 
change made by the Obliquation of the Eye is least in colours 
of the densest thin Substances.
Obs: 20. As in the 9th Observac[i]on, Soe here, the Bubble 
by transmitted light appeared of a contrary colour to that wch it 
exhibited by reflexion. Thus when the Bubble, being looked on 
by the Light of the clouds reflected from it, Seemed Redd at
its apparent circumference, if the clouds at the Same time or 
very Suddenly were viewed through it, the colour at its 
Circumference would be blew. And on the contrary when by 
reflected Light it appeared blew, it would appear Red by 
transmitted Light.
Obs: 21. By wetting Plates of Moscovy-glasse whose 
thinness made the like colours appear, the colours became more 
faint, especially by wetting the Plates on that Side opposite to 
the eye; but I could not p[er]ceive any variac[i]on of their Species. So 
that the thickness of a Plate requisite to produce any colour 
depends onely on the density of the Plate and not of the ambient 
Medium. And hence by the tenth and 16th Observac[i]ons 
may be known the thicknes of Bubbles of water or Plates of 
Moscovy Glasse, or of any other Substances wch they haue at 
any colour produced by them.
Obs: 22. A thin transparent Body, wch is denser then 
its Ambient Medium, exhibits more brisk and vivid colours 
then that wch is Soe much rarer; as I haue p[ar]ticularly observed 
in Air & Glass: for, blowing Glass very thin at a Lamp 
furnace, those Plates encompassed with Air did exhibit colours 
much more vivid then those of Air made thin between two 
glasses.
Obs. 23. Comparing the quantity of Light reflected 
from the Sev[er]all rings, I found it was most copious from the 
first or inmost, & in the exterior Rings became gradually lesse
& lesse. Also the whitenes of the first Ring was stronger 
then that reflected from those parts of the thin’d Medium 
wch were without the Rings; as I could manifestly p[er]ceive by 
viewing at a distance the Rings made by the two Object Glasses 
Or by compareing two Bubbles of water blown at distant times,
in the first of wch the whiteness appeared wch Succeeded the colours,
& the whitenes wch preceeded them in the other.
